channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Alexei Ratmansky, the New York-based choreographer, was working on a new ballet for the Bolshoi when Russia invaded Ukraine. Ratmansky, who grew up in Kyiv, left Moscow and says he doubts he'd return to Russia to work “if Putin is still president.” https://t.co/CLHFYnQEJP

The EU's executive arm will ask member nations to grant temporary asylum to all Ukrainians coming to the bloc for up to three years. More than 300,000 people have already fled Ukraine, and there could be four million more, officials said. https://t.co/TZXfedlsT8

In cities and towns in Central Ukraine that have not yet heard the boom of Russian artillery fire, residents spent the weekend preparing furiously for the possibility of an attack. https://t.co/Y2yTgqhk91 https://t.co/dbp6QKR8q7

Norway’s sovereign wealth fund, a $1.3 trillion fund, is freezing its assets in Russia and plans to divest from the Russian market, a spokeswoman said Sunday. Its Russian investments equaled 0.2% of the fund. https://t.co/jxedHL4aRY

“I made the decision to come back to Ukraine and fight.” While tens of thousands of Ukrainians have sought safety in neighboring countries, some have returned from abroad to fight against the Russian invasion and reunite with family members. https://t.co/Y0HLEviFq5 https://t.co/ohnLp4b5qh

“I am so proud of our people,” said Oksana Mudryk, the mayor of a village about 140 miles away from Kyiv. "I thought maybe three guys at most would come to patrol with me. But in one day after the war started in Kyiv, I have signed up more than 30 people.” https://t.co/FEcsneIeZN
New: The UN Security Council will meet on Sunday at 3 p.m. Eastern to call for an emergency special session of the General Assembly on the war in Ukraine. https://t.co/oYpr0ri2eK

"I can't just stay in Poland and let Russians destroy our independence." While tens of thousands of Ukrainians have sought safety in neighboring countries, some returned from abroad to fight against the Russian invasion. Watch some of them explain why. https://t.co/MzLpBZ5obz

European officials are poised to approve a new sanctions list that included the names of some 25 oligarchs, including some of the people closest to President Vladimir Putin, in another attempt to isolate him and his government. https://t.co/tqW1zguhM7

After intense street battles on Sunday, footage verified by The New York Times showed the charred remains of Russian military vehicles on the outskirts of Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv. https://t.co/BvjVhllu7f
Ukraine launched a lawsuit against Russia on Sunday in the top court of the United Nations, accusing the country of planning a genocide of Ukrainians. https://t.co/eMJsWP59D4

Much of the attention in the first days of the war in Ukraine has focused on large cities. But in the countryside, a massive grass-roots movement is underway as ordinary Ukrainians — farmers, shop owners, day laborers, taxi drivers — are taking up arms. https://t.co/Ro2W2PtW4I https://t.co/BpCef2Gdfk

Ukrainian hospitals are running dangerously low on oxygen supplies, the WHO warned on Sunday. Oxygen is needed to treat a range of patients, including the roughly 1,700 patients being treated in Ukraine now for Covid, the WHO said. https://t.co/TJnwKJej1u

New satellite images show Russian ground forces — a convoy stretched out over more than three miles of road — getting closer to Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv. The forces include infantry fighting and supply vehicles around 40 miles northwest of Kyiv. https://t.co/3noULQ0XPz

FedEx and UPS, two of the world’s largest delivery services, have halted shipments to Russia after its invasion of Ukraine. Deliveries in and out of Ukraine have also been suspended. https://t.co/X39Zg8DIyh

In a reversal to decades of German foreign policy, Chancellor Olaf Scholz pledged that the country would spend more than 2% of its economic output annually on defense. He said Russia’s invasion of Ukraine "created a new reality." https://t.co/UhkausufWq https://t.co/dKFWuFjdpW

Tens of thousands of people demonstrated on Sunday in Madrid to demand an end to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. "The world is scandalized" by Russia’s attack, the deputy mayor of Spain’s capital city told the demonstrators. https://t.co/cSdrWRxUvd https://t.co/DnHn0XVb6z

Russian forces have begun adopting siege tactics around the historic city of Chernihiv, northeast of Kyiv, the Pentagon said Sunday, in an ominous forecast of a medieval battlefield strategy that would sharply raise the number of civilian casualties. https://t.co/qZx4344t0x

President Volodymyr Zelensky has inspired Ukrainians to fight Russia's invasion — and Europeans to see Ukraine in a different light, as a victim of aggression fighting bravely for independence, freedom and democracy. https://t.co/P3Mmdoeaq1

U.S. officials say it’s not clear how President Vladimir Putin’s announcement that he was putting Russia’s nuclear forces on alert would be translated by Russian forces. But the White House called it an attempt by Putin to escalate the confrontation. https://t.co/WuLX058UFY

"I just want to live in our country, and that's all." Julia, a teacher and Ukrainian volunteer, wept as she waited to be deployed to fight Russian troops around Kyiv on Saturday. "It's awful," she said. https://t.co/W4W16Cokhd https://t.co/IaJjkQikLM

More than 100,000 people attended a peace rally and demonstration in Berlin on Sunday in support of Ukraine. Organizers, which included peace and environmental groups, unions and churches, had expected 20,000 to gather. https://t.co/FrODEswSjZ https://t.co/aZeCYxmk3u

New: BP said on Sunday that it would “exit” its nearly 20% stake in Rosneft, the Russian state-controlled oil company. The London-based oil giant also said that both its chief executive and his predecessor would resign their seats on the Rosneft board. https://t.co/X5ilWUrN1B

In Lviv, in Ukraine's west, the resistance to Russia's invasion is made up of baristas and snowboarders, accountants and lawyers, teachers and janitors. “We are ready for everything,” said Yuri, a rapper and actor. “I said no fear.” https://t.co/9OphA0RzoY

New: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Union commission, announced an EU-wide ban on all Russian aircraft. The bloc will finance the donation of weapons to Ukraine and ban Kremlin-funded broadcaster RT and extend new sanctions on Belarus. https://t.co/whyh0F7m0W

For more than a decade, Xi Jinping of China and Vladimir Putin of Russia have forged a respectful, perhaps even warm relationship. The invasion of Ukraine could upend all that — or forge an alliance that reshapes the world order in the 21st century. https://t.co/2YPIZvSIcv

Worshippers gathered for morning services at St. Paraskeva Orthodox Church in Kalynivka, Ukraine, on Sunday, as the Russian invasion of their country continued. Follow live updates from the ground here: https://t.co/dsKdmIi9eW https://t.co/n8pN5glNz9

"I just want to live in our country, and that's all." Julia, a teacher and Ukrainian volunteer, wept as she waited to be deployed to fight Russian troops around Kyiv on Saturday. "it's awful," she said. https://t.co/l3aQRtLlru https://t.co/J35Tf6a75F

At least 368,000 people have fled from Ukraine, the United Nations refugee agency said on Sunday, adding that the number "continues to rise." Ukrainians have tried to escape by train, by car and by foot as Russian forces close in on major cities. https://t.co/l4UyXvbBnO https://t.co/KQF6ued1Ys

Messages of support for Ukraine, and anger at Russia, have been written on a wall outside the Russian Embassy in London. “Putin is a killer,” “Peace in Ukraine” and “No to imperialism” have been scrawled in bright lettering on the brick. https://t.co/tPYmFvGmja https://t.co/XGO6GaZv4c

“Either we fight them off or we will all die,” said one medic in the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro, where the expectation is that the fighting could come at any time. “We’re hanging on and will do so to the end.” https://t.co/MEB83tLi1x

Russia has established attack lines into three regions of Ukraine: toward Kyiv, the capital, from the north; toward Kharkiv, from the northeast; and fanning out from Crimea in the south.
See the latest in our map tracking the invasion. https://t.co/N0xypM45Zn

The Ukrainian army, with the assistance of growing ranks of citizen soldiers, said on Sunday that it had slowed Russia’s advance by wreaking havoc on Russian supply lines while fighting to keep control over the cities of Kyiv and Kharkiv. https://t.co/CWw7ak6hfA https://t.co/vYp7iSYiG3
Breaking News: Ukraine agreed to talks with Russia “without preconditions,” even as Vladimir Putin further raised tensions by putting nuclear forces on alert. https://t.co/ClyApKLarw

Britain’s foreign secretary said Sunday she would support Britons who want to go to Ukraine to fight against Russia. In a BBC interview, she said those resisting were “fighting for freedom and democracy not just for Ukraine but for the whole of Europe.” https://t.co/InPO18ZWIT

Civilian volunteers sorted empty bottles to be used for Molotov cocktails in a parking lot in Dnipro, Ukraine, on Sunday. The city, like many others in Ukraine, is preparing for war, even though Russian soldiers are still some distance away. https://t.co/tutFVSMuZi https://t.co/34ROOFIBjW

The Biden administration and its key European allies reached a preliminary agreement to bar sanctioned Russian companies, oligarchs and government officials from using the SWIFT system, essentially barring them from international financial transactions. https://t.co/jiJteNs2yH

Belgium, Denmark, France, Iceland, Italy and the Netherlands joined at least a dozen European countries that said they were closing their airspace to Russian planes in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/aj0vbMVG4J

Chanting “death to Putin,” a crowd of Iranians defied their government, an ally of Russia, by protesting outside the Ukrainian Embassy in Tehran on Saturday night, according to videos posted on social media. https://t.co/FSdOAxsaQC

Breaking News: In response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany announced a significant increase in military spending, an astonishing reversal to decades of German foreign policy. https://t.co/N9tnhrgrsx

Russian troops have escalated their assault on Ukraine’s second-largest city, Kharkiv, according to videos and photographs analyzed by The New York Times.
https://t.co/UnXcVrdvgy

Japan announced it would join the coalition of countries blocking Russian banks from the SWIFT financial messaging system that facilitates international transactions. Follow our live updates on the Russian invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/kauvPSLAbP
President Volodymyr Zelensky rejected the Kremlin’s offer of talks in Belarus on Sunday because he said that country has taken Russia’s side in the conflict. https://t.co/A09weI5sty

A series of events this week raise questions about just how much political support at home President Vladimir Putin will be able to draw on during Russia's invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/iINFCR2RFH

Black troops played a significant role in the Civil War, one preserved in photographs and service records. But historians say the contribution hasn't been adequately honored. More than 150 years later, two Democratic legislators want to fix that. https://t.co/kerevR8DYn

Russia’s invasion has pushed tens of thousands of Ukrainians out of their homes and fleeing across borders. But unlike refugees from wars in Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan who have sought asylum in Europe over the past decade, they are being welcomed. https://t.co/Qff2d3c8VC

"It's not necessarily that the sanction policy was wrong. It's just that it's not enough," @PatcohenNYT said. Listen to the discussion about the limits of sanctions, with @RichardHaass, @SangerNYT and @ewong. https://t.co/WBq468AUVZ https://t.co/KHEHiL3AAC
Vladimir Putin, now facing sanctions, may have billions of dollars. But no one knows his true wealth or where it’s hidden. https://t.co/jhfMToUNe1

Vodka is now the target of international anger over the Russian invasion of Ukraine: The governors of New Hampshire and Ohio announced measures aimed at halting the sales of Russian-made and Russian-branded spirits. https://t.co/94bgHPrVOr
Gunfire has been reported near a children’s hospital in Kyiv, according to a local Ukrainian news outlet, TSN. Follow live updates on the war in Ukraine. https://t.co/BeKdHdJVxt
